item.title: RunEscape Game
item.dc:creator: @kupo kupo
item.description:
@kupo wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:20, topic:172822”][quote author=lawl link=topic=233021.msg2026070#msg2026070 date=1201907140]

If your new to the language you really shouldn’t be using an IDE, especially one thats going to make it feel like Visual Basic. I was recommended to use Notepad ++ when I first started so that I could learn how to read the compiler and fix errors myself. Eventually your going to want to use an IDE and that is fine but as a beginner your only hurting yourself.

i would have to disagree, an IDE only saves you time, like method list / etc instead of having to go to the docs
i cant see why you wouldnt learn from it either way
[/quote]
It could be seen from that way, or, suppose someone wants to learn java. He uses an IDE from the first day. He becomes quite good and decides to take a future in the language. He gets to where he is, and doesn’t know how to use the api.

Either way, I’d say use an IDE. But with Netbeans building the GUI, I’d have to point the finger towards just at least learn the basics before you use it.
I mean, I love Netbeans’ free design, and if anyone knows of any other IDE’s of the sort -> point me to it.[/quote]

Yeah… before I started I was only going to use it to save time on designing the graphics themselves, I pretty much did all the ‘working parts’ of it myself. Either way… I wanted to be able to display over a webpage, but oh well if anyone wants to see it I’ve pretty much got it done as I want and feel I can let it go public.

Read full topic

item.title: RunEscape Game
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:1, topic:177594”][quote author=speedster239 link=topic=233021.msg2023938#msg2023938 date=1201777905]
If your new to the language you really shouldn’t be using an IDE, especially one thats going to make it feel like Visual Basic. I was recommended to use Notepad ++ when I first started so that I could learn how to read the compiler and fix errors myself. Eventually your going to want to use an IDE and that is fine but as a beginner your only hurting yourself.
[/quote]
i would have to disagree, an IDE only saves you time, like method list / etc instead of having to go to the docs
i cant see why you wouldnt learn from it either way[/quote]
It could be seen from that way, or, suppose someone wants to learn java. He uses an IDE from the first day. He becomes quite good and decides to take a future in the language. He gets to where he is, and doesn’t know how to use the api.

Either way, I’d say use an IDE. But with Netbeans building the GUI, I’d have to point the finger towards just at least learn the basics before you use it.
I mean, I love Netbeans’ free design, and if anyone knows of any other IDE’s of the sort -> point me to it.

Read full topic

item.title: RunEscape Game
item.dc:creator: @speedster239 speedster239
item.description:
@speedster239 wrote:

Mopman:

You really don’t want to be using applets.

Agreed.

If your new to the language you really shouldn’t be using an IDE, especially one thats going to make it feel like Visual Basic. I was recommended to use Notepad ++ when I first started so that I could learn how to read the compiler and fix errors myself. Eventually your going to want to use an IDE and that is fine but as a beginner your only hurting yourself.

Good luck.

Read full topic

item.title: RunEscape Game
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:16, topic:172822”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=233021.msg2012851#msg2012851 date=1201233450]

Probably needs to be signed, lel.

I don’t know how to get it signed, but should be easy to look into

java applets cannot do System.exit() or if you put jframe.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

Yeah, I’m aware of that, but whenever I remove it from the code it still closed, thats where I’m stumped.

yes actually you can use System.exit(0), it exits the browser too

Not unless it is signed.
[/quote]

No, you can’t execute System.exit() or Runtime.exit() without the applet being signed.
Behavior depends entirely on the browser too; some will stop the applet, others will exit.[/quote]

Oic, i’ve made the browser exit before as well when using a Frame. It ran and when I clicked the exit button on the frame, it exited the browser as well.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:

[quote=“Taharok, post:15, topic:172822”][quote author=blah bah7 link=topic=233021.msg2012452#msg2012452 date=1201220248]

Probably needs to be signed, lel.

I don’t know how to get it signed, but should be easy to look into

java applets cannot do System.exit() or if you put jframe.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

Yeah, I’m aware of that, but whenever I remove it from the code it still closed, thats where I’m stumped.

yes actually you can use System.exit(0), it exits the browser too
[/quote]

Not unless it is signed.[/quote]

No, you can’t execute System.exit() or Runtime.exit() without the applet being signed.
Behavior depends entirely on the browser too; some will stop the applet, others will exit.

Read full topic

layout.setVerticalGroup( layout.createParallelGroup(javax.swing.GroupLayout.Alignment.LEADING) .addGroup(layout.createSequentialGroup() .addContainerGap() .addGroup(layout.createParallelGroup(javax.swing.GroupLayout.Alignment.BASELINE) .addComponent(jComboBox1, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE) .addComponent(jComboBox2, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE) .addComponent(jComboBox3, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE)) .addPreferredGap(javax.swing.LayoutStyle.ComponentPlacement.RELATED) .addGroup(layout.createParallelGroup(javax.swing.GroupLayout.Alignment.BASELINE) .addComponent(jButton1) .addComponent(jComboBox4, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE, javax.swing.GroupLayout.PREFERRED_SIZE)) .addPreferredGap(javax.swing.LayoutStyle.ComponentPlacement.RELATED) .addComponent(jScrollPane1, javax.swing.GroupLayout.DEFAULT_SIZE, 103, Short.MAX_VALUE) .addContainerGap()) );

You’re doing it wrong.
